summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons investigative report concerning an incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a homemade noose around his neck. The report details the incident, subsequent medical assessments, and interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, concluding there was insufficient evidence of assault and no need for a separation order. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and accompanying staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with an orange cloth around his neck. The reports describe the initial response as a suicide attempt, but later statements from Epstein allege his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, attempted to kill him and extort money. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, primarily documenting the events of July 23, 2019, when inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck. It includes staff shift logs, medical encounter reports for Epstein and his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione, photo sheets documenting the incident, an administrative detention order for Epstein, and an incident report detailing the suicide attempt.

connections.description: Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. Epstein stated he had no issues with Tartaglione, while Tartaglione reported keeping conversation minimal and being uncomfortable with some of Epstein's statements.
Officer Clarke spoke with Epstein after the incident and relayed his allegations against Tartaglione to a lieutenant.
Thomas assisted in carrying Epstein to the HA-Unit and was assigned to observe him on suicide watch.
Officer Masullo applied restraints to inmate Tartaglione during the incident response.
Were housed together in cell 124 of the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York. Tartaglione alerted staff to Epstein's condition.
Correctional Officer Masullo was involved in the response to the incident and is the reporting employee on the official incident report.
Correctional Officer Thomas was assigned to staff Epstein's suicide watch following the incident.

events.title: Epstein Found with Homemade Noose
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on his cell floor in a fetal position with a homemade noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily and responsive. He was restrained, medically examined, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Interview with Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was interviewed by SIS staff. He claimed extreme fatigue, said he got up for water and recalled being on the floor snoring. He stated he had no issues with cellmate Tartaglione, despite a prior incident where Tartaglione called him a pedophile.

events.title: Interview with Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Tartaglione was interviewed. He stated he was asleep on the floor, felt something hit his foot, and found Epstein sitting with eyes open. He called for help, thinking Epstein was having a heart attack. He reported a prior uncomfortable conversation with Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued, placing Jeffrey Epstein in detention pending classification.

events.title: Epstein Found with Orange Cloth Around Neck
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff responded, removed the cloth, and transported him to the HA-Unit.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Murder Attempt and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him for a week, threatening to beat him up if he didn't pay.

events.title: Tartaglione's Account of Discovery
events.description: Tartaglione stated he was asleep when he felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck. He then called the guards.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Following the incident, Epstein was examined by medical staff, dressed in a suicide smock, and placed on suicide watch under staff observation.

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (SHU Z05-Cell 124) with an orange homemade rope around his neck, sitting on the floor, unresponsive but breathing. Staff removed the rope and he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Medical Evaluation
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by medical staff (MLP) following the incident. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) around his neck but was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and denied pain or knowledge of how the injury occurred.

events.title: Photographic Documentation of Incident
events.description: A Lieutenant took photographs of Epstein's cell (SHU) as part of the Special Investigative Section's documentation of the possible suicide attempt.

events.title: Photographic Documentation of Cellmate
events.description: A Lieutenant took photographs of cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione in the Special Housing Unit following the incident with Epstein.

events.title: Tartaglione Medical Evaluation
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione was evaluated by a PA-C in the SHU. He stated he felt good, had no complaints, and denied any involvement or injury related to the incident with his former cellmate.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a homemade noose around his neck, resulting in neck injuries documented by medical staff.
Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, reported discovering him and calling for help, stating he thought Epstein was having a heart attack.

Tartaglione told investigators that during a prior conversation, Epstein stated 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states and I don't understand what's the problem here,' which made Tartaglione uncomfortable.
The BOP investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence to support that Epstein was assaulted by Tartaglione and recommended no separation between the inmates.
Epstein, during his interview, denied feeling suicidal, stated he felt safe with Tartaglione, and blamed the incident on extreme sleep deprivation.
On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC New York cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck, initially reported as a suicide attempt.

Epstein later alleged to staff that his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had tried to kill him and had been extorting him, claiming Tartaglione said staff wouldn't care if he was hurt due to his charges.
Tartaglione gave a conflicting account, stating he discovered Epstein with the cloth and called for guards.
Epstein was treated for a circular line of erythema (redness) on his neck and a small mark on his left knee, then placed on suicide watch.
The document includes a detailed staff roster for the day, showing the personnel assigned to the facility at the time of the incident.
On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (SHU Cell 124) with an orange homemade rope around his neck, sitting on the floor, unresponsive but breathing.
Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted staff to the incident. Epstein was removed from the cell, the rope was taken off, and he was placed on suicide watch.

A medical examination hours later found Epstein with a circular line of erythema (redness) around his neck but noted he was 'ambulatory, oriented x3... smiling during this clinical encounter' and repeatedly said 'I do not know' how the injury occurred.
Epstein had been placed in Administrative Detention in the SHU on July 10, 2019, for his own protection, pending classification.

The incident was officially documented as a 'Possible Suicide Attempt' and investigated by the prison's Special Investigative Section, which included photographic documentation of both Epstein and Tartaglione.
